facts.text: Pedigree: Chintalapati Venkatapatiraju had son Somaraj; Pullamraju (son?) died 19-12-1913 leaving undivided son Somaraju, widow Surayamma (died 22-10-1950), three daughters (Subbayyamma died 6-4-27, Venkayyamma died in infancy, Radhyyamma died 29-3-21?); daughters' descendants include plaintiffs 1 and 2 (sons of one daughter), defendant 6 (son of another), defendants 1-4.
Pullamraju died leaving surviving undivided Somaraju, widow Surayamma and three daughters.
Somaraju died on March 29, 1921; claimed to have left will dated March 26, 1921 bequeathing all properties to Surayamma absolutely.
Sitaramaraju (uncle of Pullamraju) filed Suit No. 21 of 1923 for declaration that Somaraju's will was not valid as executed when minor and not in sound disposing state of mind.

Surayamma in written statement in Suit 21/23 contended Somaraju born January 7, 1903, major, sound mind; suit ended in compromise decree admitting will genuine valid; Sitaramaraju received 26 out of 57 acres, rest retained by Surayamma.

Surayamma conducted herself as absolute owner post-decree; two deeds dated March 30, 1925 settled part of land to her two daughters (mothers of plaintiffs 1&2 and defendant 6); properties possessed by daughters then plaintiffs 1&2 and def6.
Surayamma gifted another portion to defendant No. 6 on November 3, 1947.

Plaintiffs 1&2 and defendant 6 (appellants) obtained deed of surrender from their mothers; filed suit contending nearest reversioners of Somaraju, compromise decree collusive, no will or invalid (not major, unsound mind); amendment: some lands not disposed by will, intestacy entitling them.

Trial court dismissed suit: will executed, original suppressed by appellants, certified copy admissible; Somaraju major sound mind; decree family arrangement binding; estoppel; no undisposed property or intestacy.
High Court confirmed dismissal: certified copy admissible; Somaraju major sound mind; decree binding; estoppel by acceptance.
Appellants denied possession of original will; notice given but failed to produce; courts found will in appellants' custody, deliberately withheld.
Scribe and attesting witnesses dead except D.W.4 Dalapati Venkatapathi Raju; appellants contended he not attestor.
Birth/death registers for 1903/1905 available 1955 but not 1957; extracts: Ex.B24 (resp, tampered), A4/A5 (pet, tampered, unreliable); A8/A9 inadmissible.
Will states Somaraju 19 years old; total property 60 acres 9 cents; schedule discrepancy due to survey changes 1902/1912.
Parties' conduct: Sitaramaraju and Surayamma acted on will validity; daughters/appellants accepted settlements without challenge.

legal_issues.text: Whether certified copy of will admissible as secondary evidence and proves due execution and attestation.
Whether Somaraju was a major (born 1903 or 1905) and in sound disposing state of mind when executing will.
Whether extracts from birth/death registers admissible under s.35 Evidence Act.
Whether compromise decree binding on appellants and estops challenge to will.
Whether appellants claim under Hindu Law of Inheritance Amendment Act 1929 precludes estoppel.
Whether intestacy as to ~15 acres not listed in will schedule.

petitioner_arguments.text: Burden on respondents to prove will validly executed and Somaraju major; failed.
Courts' conclusion Somaraju 19 years old not justified.
Birth/death register extracts public documents admissible under s.35 Evidence Act.
Even if will not proved, compromise decree not binding/estopping appellants.
Claim under Hindu Law of Inheritance Amendment Act 1929, not through Venkamma; no estoppel.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Law of Inheritance Amendment Act 2 of 1929

petitioner_arguments.text: Somaraju did not dispose ~A 15.14; intestacy; entitled as reversioners.

respondent_arguments.text: Will valid; compromise decree binding on appellants.
Appellants estopped by accepting/enjoying properties settled by Surayamma.
No property undisposed; no intestacy; appellants not entitled.

court_reasoning.text: Certified copy Ex.B.9 admissible as secondary evidence (original suppressed by appellants); s.90 presumption not for copy (Munnalal, Bassant Singh, Harihar Prasad); but other evidence proves execution: Surayamma produced in 1923 suit, her claim/conduct, settlements, rational terms, D.W.4 evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ample evidence will duly executed; Somaraju sound mind.

court_reasoning.text: Documents tampered/unreliable (B24,A4,A5); A8/A9 inadmissible; oral speculative except D.W.4; Somaraju's will statement (age 19) admissible s.32(5) Evidence Act (relates to relationship commencement; precedents: Oriental Govt., Ariffin etc.); Surayamma WS inadmissible post litem motam; conduct consistent with majority/validity.
No need to decide admissibility of extracts as unreliable.
Will valid so no need for contentions 4/5 on decree/estoppel.
Will expressly disposes entire 60 acres 9 cents; schedule discrepancy due to survey changes; no intent to leave intestate.

holdings.text: Certified copy proves will contents; duly executed/attested; Somaraju major/sound mind.
Somaraju's age statement in will admissible under s.32(5); proved major.

precedents_cited.relevance: No s.90 presumption for certified copy of 30yr old doc; only signatures on copy presumed

precedents_cited.case_name: Harihar Prasad v. Must. of Munshi Nath Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: Approves Bassant Singh on s.90 for copies
Certified copy admissible as secondary; court construes original terms
Onus on propounder to prove majority/competency

precedents_cited.case_name: Oriental Govt. Security Life Assurance Co. Ltd. v. Narasimha Chari
precedents_cited.relevance: Age statement admissible s.32(5) as relates to relationship

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohammed Syedol Ariffin v. Yeohoo Gark

precedents_cited.relevance: Statements admissible if ante litem motam

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of documents, extracts, statements on age/relationship, presumptions for old docs, secondary evidence

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal confirming trial court and High Court; held will validly executed by major Somaraju in sound mind, entire property bequeathed, no intestacy; no need to decide on compromise decree bindingness.

key_quotes.text: "the production which entitles the Court to draw the presumption as to execution and attestation is of the original and not its copy"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies s.90 Evidence Act applies only to originals, not copies

key_quotes.text: "a statement as to his age made by a person having special knowledge relates to the existence of such relationship"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies admissibility of Somaraju's age statement under s.32(5)

key_quotes.text: "in face of the expressly declared intention in the body of the will that he was disposing of the entire property including the land measuring 60 acres 9 cents it is impossible to hold that he desired to hold back a portion"
key_quotes.speaker: court
